data.title: Python vs Other Programming Languages: Which One ...
data.snippet:
## ‚ö° Performance

 Java is faster because it compiles into bytecode and runs on the JVM (Java Virtual Machine).
 Python is slower since it is interpreted at runtime.

## üéØ Use Cases

‚úÖ Python: Data Science, Machine Learning, Web Development  
‚úÖ Java: Enterprise Applications, Mobile Apps (Android)

üîπ Who Should Use What?

 If you‚Äôre a beginner: Go with Python üêç
 If you want to work in big companies: Learn Java ‚òï

## 2Ô∏è‚É£ Python vs C++: Simplicity vs Speed

## üìù Syntax & Readability

Python is beginner-friendly, whereas C++ is powerful but complex.

üí° Example: Simple Addition

‚úÖ C++: [...] ### üöÄ Introduction

Python is one of the most loved programming languages today, but how does it compare to other languages like Java, C++, JavaScript, and Ruby? In this article, we‚Äôll break it down in a simple and engaging way, looking at readability, performance, and use cases with basic code examples.

If you‚Äôre new to programming, don‚Äôt worry! We‚Äôll keep things easy to understand. Let‚Äôs dive in! üîç

> üìå Want a quick explanation of Python vs. other programming languages? Check out my video below where I break it down with easy examples!

üé• Watch the video here:

## 1Ô∏è‚É£ Python vs Java: Simplicity vs Structure

## üìù Syntax & Readability [...] ## üìù Syntax & Readability

Python is often called ‚ÄúEnglish-like‚Äù because its syntax is clean and easy to read. Java, on the other hand, is more structured and requires more lines of code.

üí° Example: Print ‚ÄúHello, World!‚Äù

‚úÖ Python:

```
print("Hello, World!") print"Hello, World!"
```

‚úÖ Java:

```
public class Main {    public static void main(String[] args) {        System.out.println("Hello, World!");    }} public class Main public static void main(String[] args)"Hello, World!"
```

üìå Key Differences:

 Python is dynamically typed (you don‚Äôt need to declare variable types).
 Java is statically typed (every variable must have a type).

## ‚ö° Performance

data.title: Python vs. Java Performance ‚Äì Comparison & Examples
data.snippet:
# Python vs. Java Performance ‚Äì Comparison & Examples

In the dynamic world of programming, choosing the right language is crucial. The rivalry between Python and Java is a notable one, each flaunting unique strengths suited for different project requirements. In 2023, Python‚Äôs popularity soared to 48.24%, while Java maintained a substantial market share of 35.35%.

For developers, both budding and seasoned, aligning with the right language is a cornerstone for project success. This post unveils the essence of Python and Java, delving into their performance metrics, ease of usability, and applicability in varying tasks. Your journey towards making an informed decision in your next coding endeavor begins here.

## What is Python? [...] The contrast in performance between Java and Python is pronounced, especially in scenarios demanding high-speed execution and efficiency. While Java generally outperforms Python in terms of speed, Python‚Äôs ease of use and readability might make it a more suitable choice for projects with a faster development timeline or where performance is not a critical factor.

Conclusion

## Backend Frameworks in Python and Java [...] Performance Advantages of Java vs Python

Java‚Äôs compiled nature coupled with its Just-In-Time (JIT) compiler optimizes the runtime performance, making it a preferable choice for performance-critical applications. The JIT compiler translates the bytecode into native machine code just before execution, providing a significant performance boost compared to interpreted languages like Python.

Enterprise-Level Projects and Database Connectivity

Java‚Äôs robust frameworks like Spring and Hibernate facilitate the development of scalable, secure, and high-performance enterprise applications. Its object-oriented and modular programming approach proves beneficial in managing large codebases and complex projects.

data.title: Is Python Really That Slow? - miguelgrinberg.com
Why are Python Programs often slower than the Equivalent Program ...
data.snippet:
Other interpreted languages such as Java bytecode and .NET bytecode run faster than Python because the standard distributions include a JIT compiler that compiles bytecode to native code at runtime. The reason why CPython doesn't have a JIT compiler already is because the dynamic nature of Python makes it difficult to write one. There is work in progress to write a faster Python runtime so you should expect the performance gap to be reduced in the future, but it will probably be a while before the standard Python distribution includes a powerful JIT compiler.

Share

Improve this answer

edited Jun 13, 2010 at 20:57

answered Jun 13, 2010 at 18:22

Mark Byers

844k202202 gold badges1.6k1.6k silver badges1.5k1.5k bronze badges [...] The python source code is first compiled into Byte Code. Yes, you heard me right! Though Python is an interpreted language, it first gets compiled into byte code. This byte code is then interpreted and executed by the Python Virtual Machine(PVM).

This compilation and execution are what make Python slower than other low-level languages such as C/C++. In languages such as C/C++, the source code is compiled into binary code which can be directly executed by the CPU thus making their execution efficient than that of Python.

Share

## 1 Comment

Elliott

Elliott [...] 14133 bronze badges

## 1 Comment

Elliott

Elliott

Sorry, but this isn't the only reason why python is slower. C/C++ allow a lot more precise control to make sure the program is only doing what we want it to and nothing more.

4

Aside from the answers already posted, one thing is Python's ability to change things during runtime, which you can't do in other languages such as C. You can add member functions to classes as you go.

Also, Pythons' dynamic nature makes it impossible to say what type of parameters will be passed to a function, which in turn makes optimizing a whole lot harder.

RPython seems to be a way of getting around the optimization problem.

Still, it'll probably won't be near the performance of C for number-crunching and the like.

data.title: Python vs JavaScript vs C++ vs Java vs Go: Which is Best?
data.snippet: Python is a popular programming language, but it‚Äôs not the only option out there. Here's a comparison between Python and some other common programming languages: 1. Python vs JavaScript Python: Easy to read and write; great for beginners. Widely used for web development, data analysis, machine learning, automation, and more. Interpreted language (runs directly from source code). Slower than compiled languages, but great for rapid development. Large library ecosystem (e.g., NumPy, TensorFlow). JavaScript: Mainly used for web development to create interactive front-end applications. Runs in the browser, so no setup required for basic usage. Also has server-side capabilities (Node.js). Great for real-time applications (e.g., chat apps, games). Asynchronous programming is a key feature [...] applications. Java: Strongly typed and compiled, which leads to faster execution. More verbose syntax and less flexible compared to Python. Excellent for large-scale enterprise applications (e.g., Android apps, web applications). JVM-based, which means it can run on any platform that supports Java. 4. Python vs Go Python: Slower than Go due to being interpreted. Great for quick development with large ecosystems in machine learning and web development. Go (Golang): Compiled and much faster execution. Known for simplicity, concurrency support, and scalability (ideal for building distributed systems). Used for high-performance backend systems and cloud infrastructure. Summary: Python is great for rapid development, simplicity, and versatility, particularly in data science, machine learning, [...] apps, games). Asynchronous programming is a key feature (event-driven). 2. Python vs C++ Python: High-level and abstracted, making it easier to write and maintain. Slower execution time compared to C++ due to being interpreted. Great for prototypes, scripting, and data manipulation. C++: Low-level programming language, providing greater control over hardware. Requires more code for memory management and pointers. Faster execution, making it ideal for performance-critical applications (e.g., video games, real-time systems). More complex syntax compared to Python. 3. Python vs Java Python: Simpler syntax, which makes it quicker to write code. Dynamic typing and interpreted. Suitable for quick prototyping and writing small to medium-sized applications. Java: Strongly typed and compiled,
